misconceptions.name: Implemented distance formula instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points rather than a grade-to-letter conversion program. The code never reads a single numeric grade, never uses conditional logic for grade ranges, and never outputs a letter grade, so it does not address any part of the specified grade calculator task.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can solve this problem by writing a program that reads coordinates and computes the distance between two points.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100, use conditional statements to check which range (A, B, C, D, F) it falls into, and then print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: Prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade input
Uses double variables for coordinates instead of an integer or numeric grade
No if/else or other conditional logic for grade ranges 90–100, 80–89, etc.
Outputs a distance value instead of a letter grade (A–F)
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion about the assignment requirements or mixing up this problem with a different exercise involving distance between points.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and start a new program that: (1) reads one numeric grade (0–100), (2) uses an if/else-if/else chain to test the grade ranges (A: 90–100, B: 80–89, etc.), and (3) prints the correct letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is focused on distance calculation with no mention of grades, conditionals, or letter outputs, so it clearly does not implement the requested grade calculator.

evidence.note: All input/output and computation relate to distances between points, not reading a grade or printing a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Implementation addresses wrong problem
misconceptions.description: The student's submission calculates the distance between two points (a solution to a different problem), instead of implementing the requested Grade Calculator program. The code contains none of the required conditional logic or input/output format for the assignment.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student likely submitted an incorrect file or intended to solve a different problem specified in the assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must be designed to read a single integer grade and use conditional logic (`if-else if-else`) to map that grade to a letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: Code prompts for coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) rather than a single grade
Implements geometric calculation (`Math.sqrt` and distance formula)
Lacks any conditional structure for grade ranges
misconceptions.root_cause: Incorrect file submission or profound misunderstanding of which problem to solve.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the problem description for Q3 (Grade Calculator) and write a new program that specifically implements the required input, grade range checks, and output functionality.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code perfectly solves the Euclidean distance calculation, confirming it is not the required grade calculator program. This results in zero points for all rubric criteria.

evidence.note: Input reads four double coordinates instead of a single integer grade.
Logic calculates geometric distance, completely unrelated to grade mapping.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: Output is a calculated distance, not a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Program Submitted
misconceptions.description: Student submitted code for calculating distance between two points instead of the required grade calculator program. The submitted code reads x and y coordinates and computes Euclidean distance, which is completely unrelated to the grade conversion problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted the wrong file or completed a different assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The submission should contain a program that reads a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Program reads coordinates instead of a grade
Program calculates distance instead of converting grades
Class name is 'DistanceBetweenPoints' not a grade calculator
misconceptions.root_cause: File management error or assignment confusion - student submitted code from a different problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Verify you are submitting the correct file. The program should use a Scanner to read one integer/double for the grade, then use if-else statements or a switch to map ranges to letter grades.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the submitted code implements a completely different algorithm (distance calculation) with no overlap to the grade calculator requirements. The problem statement and code are unrelated.

evidence.note: Program reads x and y coordinates for distance calculation, not a grade value
Program calculates and outputs distance; no grade conversion or letter grade mapping

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Implemented a completely different problem (distance formula instead of grade calculator)
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points instead of reading a numeric grade and mapping it to a letter grade with conditionals. As a result, there is no handling of grade input, no Boolean ranges for A–D, and no letter-grade output.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the task is to compute the distance between two points given (x1, y1) and (x2, y2), or they reused code for a different assignment without adapting it to this problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100, use conditional statements to check which range the grade falls into (A: 90–100, B: 80–89, C: 70–79, D: 60–69, F: below 60), and then print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade
No use of if/else or other conditionals to check grade ranges
Output reports a distance value instead of a letter grade
Computation uses Math.sqrt and coordinate differences instead of grade thresholds
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between assignments or copying a template solution for a different problem without modifying it to match the grade-mapping specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard the distance formula logic and rewrite main to: (1) read a single numeric grade; (2) use an if/else-if chain (or switch with ranges) to check the grade against the specified intervals; (3) print the correct letter grade string.
related_concepts: Relational and logical operators for numeric ranges
Console input and output in Java (Scanner and System.out)
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program structure, variable names, prompts, and calculations are tailored to a distance-between-points problem with no trace of grade-handling logic, so it clearly does not address the specified grade calculator task.

evidence.note: Code reads four doubles (x1, y1, x2, y2), computes a Euclidean distance, and prints it, with no grade input, no grade-range checks, and no letter-grade output.

misconceptions.name: Solved incorrect problem (Distance Calculation)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the distance between two points instead of the requested grade calculator program. This indicates a misunderstanding or misdirection regarding the assignment prompt itself.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student submitted code for a different assignment (Distance Between Points) believing it was the correct submission for the Grade Calculator task, or perhaps copied/pasted the wrong file.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task required implementing a logical structure (if/else) to map a single integer input (grade) to a corresponding letter grade (A-F).
symptoms: Code reads four double inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one integer/double grade input (0-100).
Code lacks any conditional logic for grading ranges (if/else structure).
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading the assignment requirement or submitting code for a project intended for a different scope.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the assignment prompt carefully and ensure the submitted code addresses the specific requirements of the Grade Calculator problem (reading one grade and using comparison operators with conditionals).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student code is clearly solving the 'distance between points' problem, which is entirely unrelated to the 'grade calculator' problem described in the prompt and rubric. No part of the rubric requirements is met.

evidence.note: Class name reflects another problem entirely.
Input is four coordinates, not a single grade input (0-100).
The core logic calculates distance, not a letter grade based on conditional ranges.
